title: HW2 Q1
content: Problem context: You've seen in your optimization courses how to move back and forth between constrained and unconstrained optimizations. You've seen this idea for (b) done in lecture explicitly with a hard constraint. This problem is there to help make sure you do things yourself and understand the connections more clearly. Do this problem as soon as you can, because it will help you appreciate lectures and discussions even more.
document: Problem context: You've seen in your optimization courses how to move back and forth between constrained and unconstrained optimizations. You've seen this idea for (b) done in lecture explicitly with a hard constraint. This problem is there to help make sure you do things yourself and understand the connections more clearly. Do this problem as soon as you can, because it will help you appreciate lectures and discussions even more.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>can we get an indication for the b? I only get infinite norme of delta(theta)=0 and do not really understand... I am sorry i just arrived in the US and couldn't attend previous classes.</paragraph><paragraph/></document>
comments.document: can we get an indication for the b? I only get infinite norme of delta(theta)=0 and do not really understand... I am sorry i just arrived in the US and couldn't attend previous classes.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>The infinity norm can be understood as taking the max absolute value under all values in that parameter vector. For nonzero delta_theta, you should have a nonzero infinity norm.</paragraph></document>
comments.document: The infinity norm can be understood as taking the max absolute value under all values in that parameter vector. For nonzero delta_theta, you should have a nonzero infinity norm.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Isn't the solution to $u$ in part (b) unbounded without additional constraints? For example in the trivial 1-dimensional case the objective is $(g + \frac{1}{\alpha}) \Delta \theta$ which has unbounded minimizer when $g \neq \frac{1}{\alpha}$.</paragraph><paragraph/></document>
comments.document: Isn't the solution to $u$ in part (b) unbounded without additional constraints? For example in the trivial 1-dimensional case the objective is $(g + \frac{1}{\alpha}) \Delta \theta$ which has unbounded minimizer when $g \neq \frac{1}{\alpha}$.

comments.content: <document version="2.0"><paragraph>Thank you for pointing this out! There is a typo in the question, in fact, you should penalize by the <italic>squared</italic> infinity norm:</paragraph><math>u\ =\arg\min\ g^T\Delta\theta + \frac{1}{a}||\Delta\theta||_\infty^{2}.</math><paragraph>We will update the PDF accordingly.</paragraph></document>
comments.document:
Thank you for pointing this out! There is a typo in the question, in fact, you should penalize by the squared infinity norm:

$$u\ =\arg\min\ g^T\Delta\theta + \frac{1}{a}||\Delta\theta||_\infty^{2}.$$

We will update the PDF accordingly.
